cs.CC, cs.IT, cs.DS, cs.CG, cs.SC. 

The paper deals with the problem of polynomial identity testing (PIT) and hitting-set generators (HSG), which are central topics in computational complexity theory. The paper also mentions the notion of border complexity, which is a measure of the complexity of a polynomial that lies on the border between being computable by small circuits and being computationally hard. Therefore, the most likely sub-categories are cs.CC (Computational Complexity) and cs.IT (Information Theory), which are both concerned with the study of the computational complexity of algorithms and information processing. The paper also involves the construction of explicit hitting-set generators, which is a topic in computational algebraic geometry, and thus cs.DS (Data Structures and Algorithms) and cs.CG (Computational Geometry) are also likely sub-categories. Finally, the paper mentions the use of algebraic hardness assumptions, which is a topic in cryptography and theoretical computer science, and thus cs.SC (Symbolic Computation) is also a possible sub-category.
